nodes.bodyText:
This will result in a rather annoying upgrade cycle. For every version of messages well have to release a new version of meta.
I'd suggest creating only the meta object here and copying the fields over to the message in JVM.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,63 @@
+<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
+<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
+    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
+
+    <parent>
+        <groupId>io.cucumber</groupId>
+        <artifactId>cucumber-parent</artifactId>
+        <version>2.1.0</version>
+    </parent>
+
+    <artifactId>create-meta</artifactId>
+    <version>1.0.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
+    <packaging>jar</packaging>
+    <name>Cucumber create meta</name>
+    <description>Produce the meta message for Cucumber Java</description>

+
+    <properties>
+        <project.Automatic-Module-Name>io.cucumber.createmeta</project.Automatic-Module-Name>
+    </properties>
+
+    <scm>

+        <developerConnection>scm:git:git@github.com:cucumber/create-meta-java.git</developerConnection>
+        <url>git://github.com/cucumber/create-meta-java.git</url>
+    </scm>
+
+    <build>
+        <plugins>
+            <plugin>
+                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
+                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
+                <version>3.8.1</version>
+            </plugin>
+        </plugins>
+    </build>
+
+    <dependencies>
+        <dependency>

+            <version>5.6.1</version>
+            <scope>test</scope>
+        </dependency>
+        <dependency>
+            <groupId>io.cucumber</groupId>
+            <artifactId>messages</artifactId>

nodes.bodyText: What if we moved createMeta to the messages module? That solves the upgrade cycle problem.

nodes.bodyText:
It would break the upgrade cycle but would also make the messages lib heavier.
It is actually the same problem with Gherkin. And we don't solve that by pushing Gherkin into messages either.
Seperating the message and code that derives the information would be the best way.
Pushing down would be worse then keeping it as is.

nodes.bodyText:
I don't really see the point in decoupling to be honest. Can't we simply declare a minimum supported version of messages for the library.
To give an example, we release messages version 14.0 and create-meta version 1.0 (which relies on messages v14.0 minimum).
When we do a new release of messages but do not change the Meta message, we don't have anything to do in create-meta and no release needed.
When we do change the Meta message (adding a field or whatever), we'll need anyway to update the code of create-meta to handle those changes and populate the added field.
When we do a change in create-meta (for example extracting new CI information), we don't have to bump the minimum version of messages supported.
I'm pretty sure I'm wrong somehow, but I don't see why :D

nodes.bodyText: Maybe we should make it clear that this isn't the git info but CI provided git info.
Yes that's a good point. I think that would be made clear by nesting the Git message inside CI.

I think I'd prefer a hyperlink instead of a buildId. We could name it url - it would point to the CI build.
I think we should remove name - it can be derived from remote
shouldn't it be CIDict, CISystem etc ? (with a capital I ) - although it might make the variable names a bit weird later in the code :/
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,129 @@
+import os from 'os'
+import { messages, version as protocolVersion } from '@cucumber/messages'
+import defaultCiDict from './ciDict.json'
+
+export type CiDict = { [name: string]: CiSystem }

nodes.bodyText: I prefer it as is. My personal favorite: XMLHTTPRequest, reads much better when written as XmlHttpRequest.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,129 @@
+import os from 'os'
+import { messages, version as protocolVersion } from '@cucumber/messages'
+import defaultCiDict from './ciDict.json'
+
+export type CiDict = { [name: string]: CiSystem }

nodes.bodyText: Can we avoid this dependency or only use it in test scope? When using the mvn exec:java plugin you can execute code in test scope. This way we don't need to include the main method in the jar that is distributed.

The library needs to read ciDict.json at runtime. I was going to shade it like it's done elsewhere.
Do you have a different suggestion @mpkorstanje?
Never-mind. I saw it used in the main method and figured that was it. Shading will have to do.
